This copycat Turtles recipe is always a hit and makes the perfect gift for any chocolate lover in your life! Just make sure to make an extra batch for yourself... You don't want to miss out on these irresistible sweets! Check out the full recipe below. 

Ingredients
200 grams pecans
2 cups chocolate chips
2 tablespoons coconut oil

Caramel
1/4 cup butter
1/4 cup corn syrup
1 can sweetened condensed milk (11oz)
1 1/4 cups brown sugar

Instructions
1. Place pecans in 40 small clusters, approximately 4 pecan halves in a cluster, on a cookie sheet covered in wax paper or a silicon mat.
2. Melt caramel ingredients in a saucepan over medium-high heat, stirring constantly the entire time. Once the caramel starts boiling, stir for exactly 7 minutes. Do not go over 7 minutes.
3. Spoon caramel mixture over pecan clusters.
4. Freeze for approximately 30 minutes.
5. Melt chocolate and coconut oil. If using the microwave instead of a double boiler, warm for no more than 30 seconds at a time, for no more than 90 seconds.
6. Dunk clusters in the chocolate, covering completely and dripping off excess chocolate. Place back on the cookie sheet.
7. Let chocolate dry completely, or freeze again to speed up the process.
8. Enjoy!

Notes
Check out the blog post for important notes about possible mistakes you might make and substitutions!

#Christmas #chocolate #holidayfavourites #homemade #baking #sweets #candies #Turtles #copycatrecipe #holidayrecipes

Our dear chickens have finally started laying eggs—though they picked a very strange week to start. I honestly thought that they would not lay at all this year and just start in the spring sometime. 

I’m almost brand new to chickens—especially laying ones—and have so many questions!! How do I figure out when to better catch them after laying? I went out after lunch today and even that may have been too late. 

If these are frozen, can we still eat them when they thaw out?

Why do they like the coldest spots in the coop to lay their eggs!?!? And I would love to know which chicken is laying on the shelf by the window 🐣

I guess I’ll go on a fact finding binge if my children ever get their bed time & sleep schedules together, but until then I’d love to hear your insight!

#chickens #chickensofinstagram #browneggs #newchickenmom

Whether you observe St. Lucia Day on December 13th or not, these buns are a delicious addition to your holiday recipe book. Check out the story of St. Lucia Day on the blog and the recipe for these buns below!

Ingredients
2 tbsp yeast
1 tsp sugar
1/2 cup lukewarm water
1 1/2 cups light cream
2 tbsp Saffron threads
3/4 cup sugar
1/2 cup butter
1 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp cardamom
4-6 cups flour (Start with 4, 6 is usually too much)
1/2 cup ground blanched almonds
2 eggs
1 egg white for brushing over the buns

Instructions
1. Dissolve tsp of sugar in lukewarm water. Add yeast and set aside for 10 minutes.
2. In a saucepan, combine light cream, saffron threads, sugar, butter, cinnamon, and cardamom until just before boiling. Set aside. 
3. Add eggs, flour, almonds, & cream mixture to the yeast.  Start with 4 cups of flour and gradually add 1/2 cup of flour at a time.
4. Let the dough rise until doubled.
5. Roll out the dough and cut it into strips. Brush the egg wash on your buns.
6. Bake for 15-20 minutes at 350 degrees or until golden brown.

#buns #baking #Christmas #holidayfavourites #homemade #recipes

Whether you're craving a holiday twist on traditional cinnamon buns or looking for something special for St. Lucia Day tomorrow, check out the blog to read how my first attempt at St. Lucia Day buns turned into a delicious surprise! 

Here's the full recipe: 

Ingredients
2 tbsp yeast
1 tsp sugar
1/2 cup lukewarm water
1 1/2 cups light cream
1/4 tsp Saffron threads (optional)
3/4 cup sugar
1/2 cup butter
1 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp allspice
5 1/2 cups flour
1/2 cup ground blanched almonds
2 eggs
1/4 cup melted butter
1/4 cup brown sugar
2 tbsp water
1/2 tsp vanilla
2/3 cup icing sugar

Instructions
1. Dissolve tsp of sugar in lukewarm water. Add yeast and set aside for 10 minutes.
2. In a saucepan, combine light cream, saffron threads, sugar, butter, cinnamon, and allspice until just before boiling. Set aside.
3. Add eggs, flour, and almonds to the yeast mixture. Add cream mixture a little at a time, so you don’t end up with scrambled eggs.
4. Mix dough until it is nice and elastic. Put in a greased bowl and set to rise in a warm place until doubled in size.
5. When doubled, punch down and roll into a rectangle. Spread melted butter and disperse brown sugar. Cut in thin strips.
6. Roll one half of each strip, twist, then roll other side.
7. Let buns rise to desired size. Bake at 350 for approximately 20 minutes.
8. Make a thin icing with water, vanilla, and icing sugar. Drizzle over warm cinnamon buns.

#StLuciaDay #Christmas #cinnamonbuns #holidayfavourites #homemade #baking #recipes #happyaccident

Last week we talked about starting your eucalyptus, but it's also important to start your lisianthus around this time too! Last year I started mine in two successions--one around Christmas and another in mid-January. Lisianthus is a surprisingly cold tolerant flower, so it's nice to have a slightly later flush for fall arrangements.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
New to starting them? Here's what you need to know. . . .​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
*The biggest struggle to getting lisianthus to grow from seed is to get them to germinate. keep the soil not-too-dry and not-too-moist at all times.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
*Once they are outdoors, lisianthus need generous watering to get good stem length.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
*If you're new to growing lisianthus, seed start twice as many seeds as you think you'll actually need, to allow for failure.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
*Flower farmers, there's no shame in skipping seed starting these altogether and just ordering plugs. Time is money!​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Will you give lisianthus a try? If you've tried them before, do you think they're worth the long time commitment?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
#lisianthus #flowerfarmer #farmerflorist #cutflowers #cutflowergarden #slowflowers #localflowers

Do you love fruit bread? Me neither. Hutzelbrot is the perfect substitute during the holidays and is a special treat for the entire family. Get the full recipe below!

Ingredients
2 1/2 cups dried fruit such as peaches, pears, apples, figs, apricots, prunes, cranberries, or currants
1/2 cup of raisins
5 1/4 cups unbleached white flour
1/2 cup warm water
1 1/2 tbsp dry yeast
1/2 tsp sugar or honey
1 cup liquid from cooking fruit
1 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp salt
1 tsp grated lemon or orange peel
1/2 tsp ground cloves
1/4 cup honey
1/2 cup melted butter

Instructions
1. Boil all fruit except raisins. Drain and set one cup of liquid aside for use in the bread recipe.
2. Combine sugar, yeast and 1/2 cup warm water and let yeast rise for 10 minutes.
3. Put all ingredients in a mixer and mix with a dough hook until the dough makes a nice soft ball. You can mix by hand, but it is very difficult dough to work with and don't recommend it for beginners.
4. Place dough in a greased bowl, cover with a tea towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size. This can range from 1-2 hours depending on the humidity level where you live.
5. Punch down and shape into loaves. Place in greased bread pans and poke holes in the top with a fork. Let rise for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
6. Bake at 350 for 40-50 minutes, or 25-30 minutes if you use smaller loaf pans.

Notes
Rising times vary greatly depending on how much humidity is in the air on baking day. Even though the recipe takes a long time, most of that is spent impatiently waiting for the dough to rise.

#Hutzelbrot #fruitbread #Christmas #holidayfavourites #baking #recipes #homemade

Want to wow your friends and family with beautiful, cost-effective treats this holiday season? Try these watercolour-decorated sugar cookies! They take a little bit of time, but the reward is so worth it! Get the full recipe below:

Ingredients
Sugar Cookies
1 cup salted butter
1 1/2 cups white sugar
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla
3 cups All purpose flour
2 tsp baking powder
Royal Icing
3 cups icing sugar
3/4 teaspoon cream of tartar
2 egg whites
1 tbsp water

Decoration
2 drops per colour of food colouring
3-4 drops water per colour of food colouring

Instructions
1. Cream butter, sugar, eggs, and vanilla together.
2. Mix in flour, and baking powder.
3. Cool in the fridge for 30 minutes.
4. Roll out to approximately 1/4 inch or 5mm thickness with a rolling pin on a lightly floured surface.
5. Cut into shapes with cookie cutters and transfer to a cookie sheet.
6. Bake in a 350-degree Fahrenheit oven for 8-10 minutes.
7. Cool cookies and decorate with royal icing.
8. Beat two egg whites in a clean bowl with no hint of grease.
9. Add icing sugar, cream of tartar, and water. Mix until smooth
10. Put icing in a piping bag and pipe on cookies
11. Let icing dry overnight
12. If decorating with watercolours, add the drops of water to the drops of food colouring and decorate cookies with a clean brush.

Notes
The time in the description is just for cooking one batch of sugar cookies. The royal icing should dry overnight on the cookies for the best results.

#Christmas #baking #recipes #HolidayFavourites #homemade #DIY

If you're looking for a quick, simple recipe this holiday season, try these beautiful dipped shortbread cookies! Get the full recipe below!

Ingredients
Cookies:
1 cup cornstarch,
1 cup icing sugar,
2 cups flour,
1 1/2 cups butter, softened

Decoration:
3/4 cup chocolate chips or white chocolate chips
Sprinkles of your choice. I've used a mix of coarse sugar, white sprinkles, snowflakes and silver balls in the picture, but I also like the looks of crushed candy canes.

Instructions
1. Mix all ingredients, roll dough into little balls, and place on a cookie sheet. You can chill the dough for 30 minutes before to make the dough easier to work with, but if you don't have the time it will still work without chilling.
2. Bake at 300 degrees Fahrenheit for 15 to 20 minutes. Cookies should have the barest hint of light brown at the edges. Makes 48 small cookies, or 24 larger ones
3. Set out two small bowls--one for sprinkles and another for melted chocolate.
4. Once the cookies have cooled, melt 3/4 cup of chocolate in the microwave, for 30 seconds at a time until it's smooth. Depending on the strengh of your microwave, it will be done in either 60 or 90 seconds. Do not heat for the whole duration at once, or the chocolate will clump together and be ruined. Stir between each set of 30 seconds.
5. Dip half the shortbread in chocolate and immediately dunk in a bowl of sprinkles.
6. Set on a sheet of wax or parchment paper to dry.
7. Enjoy!

#Christmas #baking #recipes #HolidayFavourites #homemade #cookies

Looking for a quick and delicious meal to start the day on Christmas morning? These baked eggs are a family favourite. Paired with some bacon or sausage and a side of toast, this recipe comes together in no time!

Ingredients
12 large eggs
1/2 cup cream
1 cup shredded cheese
salt and pepper to taste
fresh chives optional

Instructions
1. Generously grease a muffin tin with non-stick cooking spray.
2. Crack an egg into each muffin tin. Add a splash of cream. You can easily substitute milk or coconut milk.
3. Add salt and pepper to taste
4. Sprinkle approximately 2 tsp of cheddar cheese on each egg.
5. Bake in a 350 Fahrenheit oven for 15-20 minutes, or until cheese is melted and a little bubbly.
6. Add fresh chives if desired and serve

I can't believe we're almost at the start of a new year! It's time to reflect on the last year of gardening and plan for the next one. Here are my must-have cut flowers for 2023!

1-3. More Strawflowers!! More Statice!! More Amaranth!! In 2022, I was severely, severely lacking in all of these, even though I consciously tried to plant twice as many as I did the year before. 

4. Bells of Ireland. I tried to germinate 200 seeds, and I was successful with two? Maybe three? And then I killed them... It was a very sad time, and I miss them a lot. But you know, I did manage to have three that self-seeded outdoors. So, naturally, I refused to cut them and saved every single seed. 

5. Jewels of Opar. I want them because they're orange, and they would look good in fall arrangements. I struggled really hard to have enough shades of orange for my pumpkin sale this year. The flower pictured in my stories is pink, but I would pick mine before they open up (when they are still orange).

6-7. Frosted Explosion Grass and Cress. My essential textures. 

8. Saponaria. It's more cold-tolerant than Baby's Breath, and it's really just the best. 

9. Forget Me Nots. I love the shade of blue, they're cold-tolerant, and I got two successions out of them. (I planted some of them later, and it ended up working, so I was very pleased!) 

10. Bianco Centro Nero Anemones. Even though I generally don't like Anemones and am more of a Ranunculus girl, I really love this variety of Anemones for wedding work. They are a very reliable crop, and still bloomed and looked beautiful despite the bug pressure this year. 

There you have it! What are your must-grow flowers for 2023?

#cutflowergarden #cutflowers #cutflowerfarm #flowerfarmer #farmerflorist #gardenplanning #musthavecutflowers2023

Lately in my Flower Farming Course, we've be chatting about avoiding burnout next year. Most of my flower farmers were first years last year, and no matter how hard you try to "do things the right way" there's almost always an element of hustle, especially in that first year when you're trying to figure things out.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
But in the years that follow? You get to let some of the hustle go. But how?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Ask yourself these questions. . .​​​​​​​​
*What felt easy and fun?​​​​​​​​
*What were my customers asking for more of or did they seem really excited about?​​​​​​​​
*What was my best money maker?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Then ask, how can I do more of those things?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
On the flip side, ​​​​​​​​
*What felt like a ton of work for little pay off?​​​​​​​​
*What was your biggest time suck?​​​​​​​​
*What didn't sell?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Then how can you let those things go? Or if it's an essential task, find a system to make them more efficient, or outsource them?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​

The word for this year should have been "Upheaval." Why, you ask? 

Well, throughout this entire year, there were so many things going on behind the scenes that I couldn't really tell you about. And they were all very stressful and all very "upheaval." 

The ones you know: 
1. Moving to a completely new location (and all the stress of moving things and buying and selling a house)
2. Getting pregnant (while happy news, was also an upheaval and suddenly made the house look a lot smaller)
3. Updating my website (which, to put it mildly, has been a real source of frustration)

This was the year I decided to really clean house and just get it done, and there was lots of personal stuff which created even more hurdles to jump over while I was doing it. (Sorry to be a bit elusive about it, but not everybody in my life signs up to be on the internet.)

Going from underdog to CEO and hiring out work I used to do all by myself, learning to train people to work for me, and learning how to be a boss have all been huge challenges. Letting go is something I couldn't do lightly because I was scared to delegate some of those tasks and worried that my followers might think less of me if I wasn't the one doing all of the physical labour. 

And so, while a lot of these changes and struggles were ultimately things for the better good, it still made for a very tumultuous year. Because of all this, I know exactly what my word should be for 2023...

Peace. 

P.S. I'm probably not going to get it with a newborn. 

Do you have a word or intention for the year? If so, I'd love to hear about it!

#newyearseve #newyearsgoals #wordoftheyear #2023

Need something warm and delicious to help soothe a sore throat? This four-ingredient hot toddy is simple, alcohol-free, and just the thing for any cold and flu season!

Ingredients
1 cup boiling water
Juice of 1/2 a lemon
1 tsp honey
1/2 tsp cinnamon (or to taste)

Instructions
1. Set a kettle of water to boil.
2. Cut a lemon in half. Juice one of those halves, and save the other half for another cup later.
3. Add lemon juice, honey, and cinnamon to 1 cup of boiling water. Drink as needed.

Notes
Nothing except time and rest can really fix a cough, cold, or sore throat. This hot toddy will just make you feel better until your body heals.

Have you ever wondered how on earth you're going to grow a garden with babies or toddlers in tow? ​​​​​​​​​
If you're new to my profile, you might not know that I'll be having a baby in a few short days. This sweet baby will be my fourth time gardening with kids, and my third time needing to do it at a larger scale because it's my business.

Any advice I have for you generally boils down to these two points: 
*use whatever help you have available to you
*let go of your expectations

Ideally, you'll do both! 

During these past couple of years, I've had to accept that if the kids are home, I have 45 minutes tops before someone is crying and I have to quit whatever I set out to do in the garden. If I want to work in the garden during the garden during the nap, that means I'm likely working in the hottest part of the day (AKA the wrong time).

If I can't hire help, then I only pick the biggest weeds or crisis weed whatever needs it. If I can hire help, I accept that they might not do everything perfectly, but having things done imperfectly is so much better than letting things slide.

There will be a trail of green tomatoes in the high tunnel. My favourite flower will get pulled out, and someone will probably destroy at least a 10th of my seedlings. And it's okay.

I'd much rather my kids have a positive experience in the garden and have an imperfect garden, than have a perfect garden but be yelling at everyone to stay out of it every 5 minutes.

So if you're in the same phase as me, take heart. You're not alone!

Photos by @karynlovesnoah

🌱Planning to seed start perennial flowers this year? You need cold stratification!🌱 

It may sound fancy, but the process is very simple. Cold stratification is basically the process of introducing seeds to a simulated winter. All you need to do is... 

1. moisten some paper towels
2. sprinkle your seeds on top
3. place the bundled seeds in a plastic bag (make sure to squeeze out the excess air!) 
4. label your bags
5. place the bags in the fridge (preferably in the veggie crisper) for 3-4 weeks

This helps the germination process greatly! 

Not sure if your perennial seeds need to go through this process? Most seed packets should mention it somewhere on the back. If not, just google your plant's name + "cold stratification," and you should find your answer. I'm personally starting delphinium, lupin, yarrow, and eryngium this year. Check out the photo above for other common perennials that need cold stratification for spring planting!

#coldstratification #perennials #seedstarting #gardeningtips

Do you think dried flowers are outdated or ugly? I used to, too. But a couple years ago, when I saw what people were creating, I knew I needed to start arranging with them. 

The best practice is to cut your flowers when they are around 3/4 of the way open and hang them upside down in a warm, dark, dry place. If you dry them in the sun, the colour will fade. Statice and strawflowers are some of my favourite flowers for drying, and they're featured in the flower crown in this photo!

During every post-partum period, I’ve struggled with post-partum depression, post-partum anxiety, or a combo of both. The first was the worst because I was so blindsided by having an emergency c-section. I did not prepare for that possibility, and my life wasn’t set up with any reasonable supports for that outcome. I thought having PPD meant that I wouldn’t love my baby, or that I’d want to kill myself—none of which were true. So I didn’t think anything was really wrong until one day around 18 months later the fog lifted. I could laugh again. I felt like myself.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
For my second experience I did a lot better at first. I had conversations with friends and family about what I needed and to help me get help if things got too bad. But later on my increasing anxiety couldn’t be explained away. I took a business trip to New York, and I was struck with so much fear. I was scared to leave the hotel room and walk the 2 blocks to our meetings—not like me at all. I knew I needed help, but I was convinced that if I asked for help “they” would think I was an unfit mother and take my baby away. ​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
The third time I was even more prepared to manage my PPD or PPA, and oddly enough it being Covid times actually helped with keeping the worst of it at bay. But even with feeing better than the last two, like clockwork, I still felt a certain fog lift around 18 months later.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
This time? So far so good, but it’s still early days. I have to be really gentle with myself. I have to be careful not to push myself to hard too soon physically or with work. And even if this ends up being the best post-partum experience yet, I’m sure there will be a bit of a fog that lifts again sometime around 18 months.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Photo by @karynlovesnoah​​​​​​​​

I almost gave up on my YouTube channel this year. I really love making videos for the creative aspect of it, but as last summer went on and I got more and more tired with my pregnancy, I couldn’t keep up anymore. In the fall, I analyzed “the YouTube problem” from a business perspective, and I was on the fence. By Christmas, I had resolved myself to just trying to do whatever I could manage and try not to totally quit.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
But then it’s like God knew how discouraged I was getting, and he sent many of you to message me. In that week, almost every DM I got started with something like—I found you through YouTube and I LOVE your content. And it was more than that. You opened up about your gardening struggles and little bits of your lives and I found myself feeling again that it was worth it. ​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
I’m not just recording into the void. There’s a real community out there behind me, and I’m happy to share my journey with you.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Then this morning I was talking with my son, and he asked if I was close to getting my YouTube play button yet. I said I’d have to magically 6x my audience, and he sensed my frustration. What size of trays should you use for seed starting? While there’s no right or wrong answer, here’s what I’ve landed upon.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
🌱 Start everything in the small soil blocker (makes 20 cubes at once)​​​​​​​​
🌱 The longer it needs to be started inside, the bigger the tray. Earlier started plants get put in the 50 size, and anything 6 weeks and later gets put in the 72 size.​​​​​​​​
🌱 Pumpkins are started in larger newsprint pots at 3-4 weeks (unless I’m direct sowing)​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
What do you prefer to start in? Do you use a combo of trays and soil blocking like I do? Or one or the other?​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​

It's not too late to start your anemones and ranunculus! If you're soaking corms for the first time this year, here are a few quick tips for successful flowers.⁠
⁠
1. Soak your corms for 4-6 hours--overnight is also okay.⁠
2. Presprout your corms in a cool, dark place for around 2 weeks. Once most of them get little roots and greenish bits, it's time to get them under a grow light.⁠
3. Anemones love the cold! You can plant them outside under cover around a month before your last frost.⁠
⁠
Confused about the process? Search "How to Soak and Pre-Sprout Anemones (and Ranunculus)" at shiftingroots.com!

It was 2019 and I was newly post-partum with my first daughter. It was probably silly to go, but I was determined to check out Gardenscape. I had recently niched down on my blog and was officially a garden blogger—there was no way I was missing it! So armed with the stroller and a wrap in case she was fussy, I was off!​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
The show was such a welcome breath of fresh air. There were blooming spring bulbs everywhere and the promise that spring would be there soon. I’ll never forget the U of S garden display, with the different shades of lettuce and kale so artfully arranged on the diagonal. I would try to recreate my own version that very spring.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
And then I remember seeing the speakers. I wondered if I would ever know enough or be good enough to get up on stage. And wouldn’t you know it, 4 years later, newt post-partum with my third daughter, I got my chance.​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
Thank you so much to everyone who came out to my talks this weekend. Seeing you in the audience meant so much to me. ​​​​​​​​
​​​​​​​​
I hope that this is just the beginning of many speaking engagements. If you know of anyone or are looking for a speaker on gardening or online business, let’s chat! ​​​​​​​​

This weekend was wild—and not in the good way one would hope. Yesterday morning one of my readers let me know that she couldn’t get into one of my posts she was trying to read. It seemed odd to me, so I gave her another way to try. She sent me a screenshot of what was happening. I got sick to my stomach.

I’d been hacked. Or more accurately, pirated.

In the 5-10 minutes that we were messaging, all of the urls on my site were being redirected by hackers to their scam site.

My imagination went wild. Would 7 years of hard work be wiped away in a matter of minutes? Would they hold my site hostage and I’d have to pay to get it back? Or if we did get it back would certain posts and things be lost?

Thankfully I have a good host that was able to kick the hackers out within a few minutes, and a developer who can further fix the issue with the plug-in that caused the breech.

But what a scary and stressful day!

So it was a really nice thing to wake up to 15K followers today on IG. While it’s “just a number” it’s also 15 000 of you who trust me with your gardens—and I don’t take that lightly. So thank you so much for being here!! I have a couple of giveaways planned already for April, but should I do another one for 15K? And if so, what should I give away?

Photo by @karynlovesnoah

Sometimes as we’re building our gardens, it’s tempting to quit because you can’t do everything you want to perfectly. I get it.

You’re not. Gardening is about fun and peace—not unattainable perfection. Even the most perfect garden has weeds, and even the most experienced gardener has killed something. You’re doing better than you think.

Do you have strawberry and/or rhubarb harvests that you want to transform into something delicious? Try this simple jam with pectin! Get the full recipe below.

Ingredients:
4 cups chopped rhubarb
2 cups sliced strawberries
5 cups white sugar
1 tbsp lemon juice
1 package pectin

Instructions:
1. Chop rhubarb into small pieces, and core and slice strawberries.
2. Sterilize jars you'll be using for canning be either boiling for 10 minutes, running through a bottle sterilizer, or cooking in the oven for 10 minutes at 275 degrees Fahrenheit. Boil the lids and rings in water for 10 minutes.
3. Cook rhubarb, strawberries, sugar and lemon juice in a tall pot. Mash with a potato masher as fruit softens.
4. Cook on medium high heat, stirring frequently. Add the pectin when the mixture boils.
5. The pectin package says to boil for one minute, but I frequently find that my jam never sets with that short of a boil. I suggest boiling for 3-5 minutes.
6. Turn off heat and pour jam into sterilized jars, leaving 1/4 inch headspace..
7. Clean off any spillage on the rims with a clean cloth.
8. Put on lids and secure with rims. Boil in water for 10 minutes. The water must be at least 1 inch over the top of the jars.
9. Remove after 10 minutes and set jars on a clean towel. Do not tilt the jar as you remove it, as that could compromise the seal. Do not move jars for 24 hours.
10. If you have any jars that don't seal, or a jar with too much headspace, put it in the fridge and use that one first.

Notes:
If you live at a higher altitude, you will need to boil everything for longer to sterilize it. Before trying this recipe, please consult an altitude adjustment guide for home canning!

Are you running out of freezer room but still have buckets of Saskatoon berries to preserve? Canning Saskatoon berries is surprisingly easy. Even beginner canners can master it! Get the full how-to below (and read more at shiftingroots.com/how-to-can-saskatoon-berries).

Ingredients:
approx. 8 cups Saskatoon berries
4 1/4 cups water
1 cup white sugar

Instructions:
1. Clean Saskatoon berries. Remove all leaves, stems, or blemished berries.
2. Sterilize jars, rims, and lids.
3. In a separate pot, combine water and sugar. Cook until the sugar dissolves and the water has boiled for 1 minute.
4. Add cleaned Saskatoon berries to hot, sterilized jars, filling to the bottom of the rim.
5. Fill jars with very hot water and sugar mixture, leaving 1/2 inch or 1 centimetre headspace. Seal with rims and lids.
6. Transfer to the boiling water bath and boil for 10 minutes.
7. Remove and let sit for 24 hours. Put any jars that don't seal in the fridge for immediate use.

What's your favourite way to preserve berries? Let me know in the comments!

Ready to use up some of your Saskatoon berries? This delicious pie is the recipe for you! It works perfectly with fresh or frozen berries. 

Ingredients
Filling:
10 cups Saskatoon Berries
1 2/3 cup sugar
1/2 cup all-purpose flour
2 tbsp lemon juice

Crust:
4 1/2 cups flour
1 1/2 tsp salt
1 1/3 cup shortening
8 to 10 tbsp cold water

Instructions
1. Clean Saskatoon berries and mix in sugar, flour, and lemon juice.
2. Crust: Mix flour and salt in a large bowl. Cut in shortening with a pastry blender, or your hands. When the mixture looks like a bunch of little pebbles, add cold water until combined. Let dough rest in the fridge for 10-30 minutes and roll out.
3. Cover the pie plate with dough and trim the edges that go over the pie plate with a knife.
4. Fill with 3-5 cups of Saskatoon Berries, depending how full you like your pie and how large of a pie plate you are using.
5. Cover the pie with another circle of dough, and poke holes all over the crust with a fork or knife. If you want to make a lattice crust as pictured, here's how. If you like the braided look, cut out twelve long strips of pie dough, and make four braids before following the instructions to make a lattice.
6. At this point, you can freeze the pie if desired.
7. If you are baking the pie immediately, brush on a bit of milk with a pastry brush (or your fingers) and sprinkle with a pinch or two of white sugar. This will help your crust get a nice brown to it.
8. Bake at 350 degrees for 60-75 minutes. The pie is done when The fruit is bubbling through and the crust is golden brown.

If you're a fan of blueberry muffins, you'll adore this Saskatoon berry recipe! You can use fresh or frozen berries, and the addition of Greek yogurt ensures they never dry out. Get the full recipe below!

Ingredients:
1 3/4 cups flour
1/3 cup sugar
2 teaspoons baking powder
1/4 tsp salt
1 beaten egg
3/4 cup milk
1/2 cup plain Greek yogurt
1/4 cup cooking oil
1 cup Saskatoon berries or blueberries
1 tsp lemon zest

Instructions:
1. Mix all dry ingredients and make a well in the bowl.
2. Add in the beaten egg, milk, yogurt, oil, Saskatoon berries, and lemon zest. Mix until just combined. The dough will be quite thick.
3. Line a muffin tin with liners and spoon in batter. Bake at 400 degrees for 18-20 minutes or until golden brown. Check for doneness by inserting a toothpick in the centre of one muffin. If it comes out clean, the muffin is ready.
4. Cool for 5 minutes and serve.

Brussels sprouts are typically hard to grow, and I've failed more than once trying to grow them. The key is you need to start them earlier than you think is necessary! 

This year, I have three beautiful Brussels sprout plants, and I'm pleased that two of them are a lovely shade of purple. These ones are grown from seeds from The Incredible Seed Company, and, even though the seeds were quite old, I still didn't have any problems with germination!

If bugs are a problem for your Brussels sprouts crops, make sure you're giving them some diatomaceous earth from time to time, so that the creepy-crawlies stay away. You should be able to harvest sometime in late September or October, as Brussels sprouts usually taste better after a freeze!

It's been a while since I've shared this recipe, but it's so simple, incredibly delicious, and a perfect way to use up raspberry harvests! Check out the full recipe for my white chocolate raspberry scones below.

Ingredients
4 cups flour
1/2 cup sugar
2 tbsp baking powder
3/4 cup salted butter
2 eggs, beaten
1 cup light cream (6%) or milk
1 cup fresh raspberries
1 cup white chocolate chips

Topping
1/2 cup white chocolate chips
small drizzle of oil
1/4 cup powdered sugar for garnish (optional)

Instructions
1. Mix flour, sugar, and baking powder. Cut in butter until it is in small “pebbles.” Add eggs and cream and mix until almost combined. Carefully stir in raspberries and white chocolate, taking care not to mix the raspberries too much (unless you want your scones to be purple).
2. Lightly flour a flat surface, and arrange dough into two circles, approximately 8-9 inches in diameter. Cut each circle into 8 wedges. Bake at 400 degrees F for 15 minutes.
3. When cooled, microwave the 1/2 cup of white chocolate with a drizzle of oil for 30-60 seconds. Drizzle melted chocolate over the scones and top with icing sugar if desired.

The summer days have a beautiful sameness to them: get up, make coffee, check the chickens, check the garden, water the garden, and so on. The air is scented and sweet. The sun feels warm on my skin, and I look forward to waking up every single morning.

Each day, there's a new discovery. The speckled pumpkin that seems to get bigger every time I look at it. The first dahlia finally in bloom: a gorgeous coral-red Groovy variety. More zinnias than I ever could've dreamed of. And random little surprises, like this year's first sunflower (which I didn't plant, so the birds must have)!

Maybe you're not feeling as excited about your garden as I am. Maybe for you, this has been a really hard year and things just haven't worked out the way that you've hoped. You could take one of two options! 

Option one is to keep pushing through. It's so close to August that if you just keep weeding and watering for one or two more weeks, you're sure to see some sort of harvest or some amount of blooms--and it will be worth it!

The second option is to just cut your losses and declare it a beach summer. And that's totally okay, too! I was recently listening to an episode of The No-Till Flowers Podcast where they talk about how you could just mow down your weeds, sow a cover crop of buckwheat, and call it a day. And, of course, it was in a different context in this podcast, but I think it's an important lesson for us gardeners to learn.

If things don't work out, start over and give back to the soil.

Need something sweet to cool down on a hot July afternoon? Try this no-churn raspberry chocolate ice cream! Get the full recipe below.

Ingredients
1/2 cup chocolate chips
1 tsp coconut oil
2 cups whipping cream
1-2 cups fresh raspberries
1 cup white sugar
1 cup melted salted butter
1 tsp vanilla
1 cup skim powdered milk

Instructions
1. Melt chocolate and coconut oil in the microwave for 30 seconds. Stir and spread out on a piece of parchment paper or silicon mat. Freeze for 15 to 30 minutes and break into chunks
2. Whip whipping cream for approximately 2 minutes or until soft peaks form. Add sugar, melted butter, skim milk powder, and vanilla. Whip for 1 more minute.  Add raspberries and chocolate and stir until combined.
3. Put mixture into a freezable container and freeze for at least six hours, preferably overnight. Serve and enjoy!

New to canning? 

To get you started, here are my quick tips for water bath canning: 
- start with a small batch of jam (in my opinion, the easiest recipe for beginners!)
- leave the right amount of headspace when filling your jars (the distance between the rim of the jar and the liquid in your recipe)
- make sure the boiling water covers your filled jars by at least one inch at all times
- leave your upright jars in the same location for at least 24 hours after boiling

If you built raised beds this year and didn't get soil in them in time, don't despair! You can make Hugelkultur-style raised beds throughout the season! 

As you clean up your garden or trim trees, just put everything you would normally put in the compost in your raised beds to build it up. Start with logs, branches, twigs, and trees. Then add leaves and grass and top it with soil. In the grand scheme of things, the order doesn't matter much, but by doing it this way, the contents can settle and compress. This will mean you don't have to add a bunch of extra soil later on because the compression has already happened!

Have any questions about making Hugelkultur raised beds? Let me know in the comments!

P.S. If you want to feel better about your unfinished garden projects, check out these photos of my newest raised beds. Filled with compost, but sadly, no plants! Next year, I hope to fill them up just like the raised beds in the first photo!

Looking for a delicious, simple pie to make this summer? Try this easy sour cherry pie recipe!

Ingredients
Filling:
6 cups pitted sour cherries
2 cups white sugar
1 heaping tbsp flour

Crust:
2/3cup lard or butter
2 cups flour
3-6 tbsp cold water

Instructions
1. Pit sour cherries if you haven't done so already. The additional time in the recipe is how long you should allow yourself to pit the cherries.
2. Combine cherries, sugar, and flour in a bowl.
3. Combine pie ingredients in a large bowl. I personally prefer to mix with my hands, as I get a more well-mixed and workable pie crust. Add more water if too dry or more flour if too wet.
4. Divide the dough into two balls.
5. Roll out one pie dough ball and set into a 9-inch pie plate. Trim the edges with a knife.
6. Pour cherry mixture into pie shell. If your plate is not very deep, you may only use 4 cups of the cherry mixture.
7. Roll out the other pie dough ball and use to cover the pie. If you are not making a lattice crust, poke holes in the crust with a fork.
8. Seal the dough by pressing a fork around the edges. Trim any excess with a knife.
9. Bake for 375 degrees for approximately 60 minutes. The time will vary depending on your oven. The pie crust should be golden brown when finished.
10. Let cool slightly and top with whipped cream or ice cream.

Notes
This recipe uses two cups of sugar, but you can easily change the amount to suit your own tastes. I would use 1 cup if you like sour foods, 2 cups for most people, and 3 cups if you're making these for kids or don't enjoy sour foods as much. I personally do 2 cups if I plan on serving with whipped cream or ice cream and 3 if I think I'll be serving plain.

I used pre-made pie crust here to make my pie fancy for the picture. If you want to make a fancy pie crust like this, you'll get better results using pre-made dough instead of the pie-crust recipe.

If you've ever had yarrow stuck in your lawn, you probably consider yarrow a weed. However, I personally love yarrow and think everyone should grow it! It's colourful, drought tolerant, and so easy to grow. You can pick some up from virtually any place that sells plants or you can easily start it from seed.

If you love New York Cherry Cheesecake ice cream, try this recipe! With sour cherries and sweetened condensed milk, this simple, cool treat will be a hit with any sweet tooth in your life. Get the full recipe below!

Ingredients
2 cups whipping cream
1 cup salted butter, melted
1 cup white sugar
1 cup powdered skim milk
2 tsp vanilla
1/2 brick cream cheese
2 tbsp water
2 cups sour cherries
sugar to taste, try 1/2 cup
1 tbsp cornstarch
5 graham crackers

Instructions
1. If making your own cherry pie filling, heat two cups of cherries and 1/2 cup of sugar on medium-high. Mix cornstarch with a tiny bit of water to make a smooth liquid. This will prevent clumps.
2. Add to the cherries when they start to bubble. Stir for a minute or two or until it reaches desired thickness. (It should be quick. If not, add more cornstarch.) Set aside and let cool.
3. Whip the 2 cups of whipping cream until soft peaks form, about 2 minutes. Set aside.
4. In a food processor, combine butter, sugar, skim milk powder and vanilla until very well blended. Do not worry if there is still a bit of graininess; you will not taste it. Skip this step if using pre-made sweetened condensed milk. Set aside.
5. Blend the cream cheese with 2 tbsp water until smooth. In a large bowl, combine whipped cream, sweetened condensed milk mixture, and cream cheese to form the ice cream base.
6. In a large baking pan, pour half the ice cream base and top with half the cherry pie filling. Crumble two graham crackers and spread.
7. Repeat the process. Mix lightly with a spatula. Top with one last graham cracker for presentation.
8. Cover tightly with saran wrap and set in the freezer overnight. Your ice cream may be ready in as little as 6-8 hours, but mine wasn’t.
9. Set out for 5-10 minutes before you’re ready to serve. Enjoy!

This classic red relish may seem like an unusual canning recipe, but I promise you'll love this deliciously sweet and tangy tomato topping. It's my go-to condiment for hamburgers, hotdogs, sausage on a bun, and more! Get the full recipe below.

Ingredients
2 cups chopped cucumbers (unpeeled)
2 cups chopped sweet red, yellow, orange, or green pepper
2 cups chopped zucchini
1 cup chopped onion
1/4 cup pickling salt
4 cups chopped seeded peeled tomatoes
3 cups white vinegar
1 tablespoon mustard seeds
1 teaspoon turmeric
1 teaspoon cinnamon
1 teaspoon allspice
1 teaspoon ground cloves
2 cups granulated sugar

Instructions
1. The night or at least 8 hours before you plan on canning the relish, dice the cucumbers, zucchini, onion, and peppers. Put them in a large bowl filled with water, and add 1/4 cup pickling salt.
2. The next day, drain the water and rinse the vegetables. Squeeze out as much of the water as you can.
3. Chop up your tomatoes and remove as many seeds as possible. I like to chop my tomatoes in half and squeeze out the seeds. You won't get everything, but it is a lot quicker.
4. In a large saucepan, bring your tomatoes, vinegar and spices to a boil, stirring often.
5. Reduce heat to medium & simmer for 30 minutes.
6. Add in sugar & drained vegetables. Bring to a boil again, and simmer for another 20 minutes.
7. Fill & seal jars, processing in a water bath for 15 minutes. (Adjust your time if you live at a higher altitude.) My favourite way to sterilize jars is to cook them in the oven at 235F for at least 10 minutes. It is much more efficient than boiling them, and you save precious stove room & counter space.

Not sure what to do with all those crab apples? Try this maple spice crab apple butter! It's delicious with both sweet and savoury dishes. Get the full recipe below!

Ingredients
5 cups apple sauce
1 cup apple juice
1/2 cup maple syrup
1/2 cup brown sugar
1/4 cup lemon juice
1 tbsp cinnamon
1 tsp allspice

Instructions
1. Clean and cut your crab apples, removing all stems, cores, and blossom ends.
2. Fill a large pot approximately 1/2 full of crab apples. Add four cups of water and boil. You may need to add more water as your apples cook so they don't burn.
3. When the apples are cooked through and mushy, remove from heat and put them in a blender. Blend on medium-low for 30 seconds or until smooth.
4. Measure out five cups of crab apple sauce and return to the pot. Add apple juice. I use the crab apple juice I make, but apple juice from the store is fine too. Add maple syrup, brown sugar, lemon juice, cinnamon, and allspice. Feel free to adjust the spices to suit your tastes.
5. Heat and cook until boiling. Set heat to medium-low and simmer for approximately 15 minutes. Transfer to sterilized jars and process in boiling water for 10 minutes, or let cool and store in freezer-safe containers.

Are white spots starting to appear on your squash or cucumber plants? This is called powdery mildew! While you can't reverse it, you can prevent it from spreading further! 

It's as easy as removing the badly infected leaves and throwing them in the garbage (not the compost, as you don't want those white spots to spread!), then spraying the remaining leaves with a milk and water mixture!

For more about powdery mildew and my exact process of treating it, check out "2-Step Solution to Control Powdery Mildew" at shiftingroots.com!

I smacked the clay on the wheel, and I wanted to cry. 

For so long, I've dreamed of making pottery, so I finally took the leap and went to a class. But things didn't go as I imagined... I cut my finger on one of the tools before we even got started, my teacher got very annoyed with me, and everything I made just felt completely disastrous.

As discouraging an experience as it was, it got me thinking that maybe this is how you feel in your gardens. It was humbling. Maybe this year wasn't the perfect garden you'd been dreaming about. Maybe everything got covered in weeds. Maybe you forgot to water, and your plants didn't do very well. Or maybe you barely got a harvest. Whatever happened, you probably feel a lot like I felt at the pottery wheel--like a complete failure, like you shouldn't do this anymore, and like you pretty much just want to quit.

But please, please, don't give up! 

The only difference right now between you and me is that I've killed a lot more plants than you have. As I was trying to choke back those tears, I realized that the only difference between me and my teacher was that she'd spent way more time at the pottery wheel than I had. 

So chin up, fellow gardeners! Next year will be better, and I promise that all those failures you're experiencing this year will help you be a much better gardener next spring!

Photo by @juli_labrecque_photography

#beginnergardener #beginnerpottery #lifelessons #gardenlife #gardeningtips

When I first started gardening, I did what my parents always did: I pulled almost everything out around the September long weekend. However, since I've moved out to the acreage and we've struggled with both our soil health and a lack of water, I now leave everything in the ground and only pull out diseased plants. 

At first, I was very skeptical. I thought that this would be very messy and I wouldn't like it. However, after seeing how much more snow melt we got and how much the soil health improves from leaving the roots in the soil, I am a believer.

So, if you choose to do things my way, you're not a lazy gardener! You're just working on your soil health and getting more moisture. And, while you're not busy cleaning up your garden, here are some other tasks you can complete at this time of year!

On our acreage, there's no shortage of stories and characters. 

I've been eagerly looking forward to my new set of chickens laying their eggs for weeks. But when the four-month mark hit, only one chicken started laying. Gradually, as time passed, a few more chickens started laying each week until I knew there were maybe only one or two holdouts. 

From previous experience, I knew all my chickens should be laying by September 17th (which is coming up very soon!). I knew this hold-out chicken must be laying eggs somewhere in the yard because I would hear the egg song in the afternoon but could never find the eggs. 

On Sunday, however, I heard the egg song and saw a chicken in the raised garden beds! I knew that this was my chance!! I searched all the obvious places and saw no eggs. Finally, I lifted the big boxes in there, and, lo and behold, I found the clutch of eggs and... 

I also found Mama Cat with the brand-new babies she'd had the night before!

I'm sure there's a joke somewhere in there about which came first, the kitten or the egg, but until I find this funny, I'm just shaking my head at how ridiculous the animals on our acreage are. So, I'll be watching our mama cat like a hawk over the next few days. She tends to move her babies every 2-3 days, and when she does, I'm gonna swoop in there and get those eggs!!

P.S. I know that by doing this, I risk getting my scent on those babies and Mama Cat possibly rejecting them. However, she is definitely going to reject some of those babies anyway. She's unfortunately not a big enough milk producer to feed a litter of kittens the size she just had. 

P.P.S. I've included some of my favourite photos from @juli_labrecque_photography of our animals, but you can scroll to the end to see Mama Cat and her babies (and the eggs)! 

#gardeningwithcats #gardeningwithchickens #eggs #chickens #kittens #acreagelife #homesteading #zone3gardening #saskgarden #farmstories

It's pumpkin spice season! Looking for a delicious, simple recipe to make for Thanksgiving (or just for fun)? Try these pumpkin spice cupcakes with cream cheese icing!

Ingredients
Cupcake
4 eggs
3/4 cup brown sugar
1 cup canola oil
2 cups pureed pumpkin
2 cups flour
2 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon allspice
1/2 teaspoon ginger
1 teaspoon vanilla

Icing
1 8-ounce package cream cheese, softened
4 cups icing sugar
1/4 cup salted butter, softened
1 teaspoon vanilla
1 teaspoon cinnamon

Instructions
1. Beat eggs and slowly add sugar, oil, vanilla and pumpkin, beating well.
2. Add dry ingredients and stir until moistened.
3. Line two muffin tins and spoon in the batter.
4. Bake at 350 degrees F for 25 minutes or until an inserted toothpick comes clean. Remove from muffin tin and cool.
5. To make the icing, put cream cheese, icing sugar, butter, vanilla and cinnamon in a mixing bowl. Beat slowly at first, working your way to medium speed. Add more or less icing sugar to suit your tastes.
6. Pipe icing on cooled cupcakes and serve.

While I know it's important to put my face into the business, this year I've struggled more than usual with it. If you're new here, you might not know that I had a baby this January! Unfortunately, with all four babies, I've gotten some concoction of postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety. And, this time, PPD hit me the hardest of all four children. 

As a result, one of the things that went by the wayside was sharing my face. Sure, you've seen all the beautiful photos Juli has taken of me, but when I would go to take reels or make stories, I would get a pit in my stomach knowing I just wasn't ready yet to show something a little less manicured and raw. Then, this weekend, I did a market and realized over the three days that probably about 70% of the people who showed up for me were people who are interacting with this account frequently. And, in part, you showed up because I show my face and hopefully provide some value to you on a daily basis.

So, even though I'm not entirely out of the woods yet, I will be showing up. Because I know it's important to keep my connection with all of you. If you're struggling with your mental health, your health should always come before your business. But this next part is for those of us who have something a little lighter preventing us from showing our faces. Those of us who have society's standards ringing in our ears about our body image, not having the right makeup, or some other unattainable thing we've been told. I encourage you to show up no matter what! Because your audience won't care if you have a full face of makeup or "need to" lose 50 pounds. They'll like you because you're you.

If you don’t have these 3 things right, expect dead, mouldy, or dried out tubers. 😰

Most people can usually find a place that gets 1 and 2 right, but temperature is a struggle! You’re looking for a place that stays between 2°C-10°C until March or April when it’s time to wake them up again.

In an attempt to be a better YouTuber, I’ve recently been watching all sorts of YouTube creators that aren’t related to my niche in the slightest. One of those whom I really enjoy is finance YouTuber Caleb Hammer. 

If you’ve never watched him before, the gist is this: people come onto his show, he reviews their finances, their finances are terrible, he gets angry and annoyed at their bad decisions, and then he helps them with a lot of compassion and understanding. 

I’ve been watching many episodes, and one of my favourites by far is when he got Graham Stephan to interview him on his own finances. I had never heard anyone explain their finances in terms of anxiety exactly like Caleb had before, and then when he revealed he was also a former musician, I felt like I loved him even more. 

There were two episodes I watched recently where I came to understand that his guest's bad financial decisions were not just bad financial decisions. They were essentially a cry for help. 

The people he interviewed were trying to improve their internal struggles or make them go away by eating fast food or spending money on unnecessary stuff. In response to this behaviour, he told someone he thought should almost claim bankruptcy, “You matter. You are worth fighting for." 

Then it hit me–I’m not living my life like I matter. 

And I bet many of you reading this probably aren't, either. 

I don't think that means we need to start being particularly selfish and adopting a “me me me” lifestyle. But I realized that in my day-to-day choices, I need to act like I matter to myself instead of always putting my kids, my husband, my job, the house, and a million other things before my own well-being. 

So, this has nothing to do with gardening, but it’s just been a big mind shift I've had recently that I wanted to share with you all. I hope it helps you on your own journey of self-discovery and care. It’s sure been helping me on mine.

#newdiscoveries #motivation #selflove #selfcare #selfdevelopment #mindset #inspiration #personaldevelopment #personalgrowth #selfhelp #mentalhealth #growthmindset

I'm starting this year's holiday recipe sharing with one of my most popular recipes: Homemade Turtles Candies! You'll get at least 40 chocolates from this recipe and the bragging rights you made your own. You can also substitute walnuts in for the pecans to save a little extra money, and they turn out just as well! 

Check out the full recipe below and impress your friends and family this holiday season!

Ingredients⁠⁠
200 grams pecans⁠⁠
2 cups chocolate chips⁠⁠
2 tablespoons coconut oil⁠⁠
Caramel:⁠⁠
1/4 cup butter⁠⁠
1/4 cup corn syrup⁠⁠
1 can sweetened condensed milk (11oz)⁠⁠
1 1/4 cups brown sugar⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Instructions⁠⁠
1. Place pecans in 40 small clusters, approximately 4 pecan halves in a cluster, on a cookie sheet covered in wax paper or a silicon mat.⁠⁠
2. Melt caramel ingredients in a saucepan over medium-high heat, stirring constantly the entire time. Once the caramel starts boiling, stir for exactly 7 minutes. Do not go over 7 minutes.⁠⁠
3. Spoon caramel mixture over pecan clusters.⁠⁠
4. Freeze for approximately 30 minutes.⁠⁠
5. Melt chocolate and coconut oil. If using the microwave instead of a double boiler, warm for no more than 30 seconds at a time, for no more than 90 seconds.⁠⁠
6. Dunk clusters in the chocolate, covering completely and dripping off excess chocolate. Place back on the cookie sheet.⁠⁠
7. Let chocolate dry completely or freeze again to speed up the process.⁠⁠

Enjoy!⁠⁠
⁠⁠

There are many times when messages will pop into my inbox saying something to the effect of "Thanks for all you do" or "I really appreciate your content because of x, y, or z." One of these messages has really stuck with me over the years.

Her name was Sindy, and she had read one of my posts where I'd talked about how there is never a right time to do anything. I felt like, personally, in my life, there would never really be a perfect time- I would never be thin enough, my children would never be the right ages, I would never have the perfect house, and so on and on and on. Sindy messaged me and said she took it to heart, and it ultimately helped her decide to start a YouTube channel with her husband Dan, which had been on their hearts for quite a while: Simple Life Portugal.

We chatted a bit extra, as we were both Canadian and both on this YouTube journey figuring things out as we went. I would check in often to see the progress on Sindy & Dan's homestead and to see how everything was going. It was inspiring to see her and her partner build their lifelong dream together step by step.

I found out a couple of days ago that Sindy passed away from cancer.

My heart is so very heavy. She was truly a beautiful person- inside and out. And she will be dearly missed. It goes to show that none of us know the true impact we're making when we post to our nine squares (if you're on Instagram) or to our other feeds. Social media often gets a bad rap (deservedly so), but it can also do some very beautiful things in our lives. Often, it can bring us closer together, even when we're miles apart. And, even when it feels easier to sit on the sidelines of our own lives, it can inspire us to follow our dreams.

Photo by @juli_labrecque_photography

#gratitude #community #connection #followyourdreams

This holiday recipe is a classic: Melt-in-your-Mouth Shortbread! The secret is in the cornstarch. It gives the dough a much smoother texture, making it a lot easier to work with. Bonus? This recipe yields 48 cookies and only uses four ingredients! 

Ingredients
1 cup corn starch,
1 cup icing sugar,
2 cups flour,
1 1/2 cups butter, softened

Instructions
1. Mix all ingredients and spoon onto a cookie sheet 
2. Optional: chill for 30 minutes and roll out for a cut cookie
3. Apply sprinkles or cherries before baking
4. Bake at 300 degrees Fahrenheit for 15 to 20 minutes. Cookies should have the barest hint of light brown at the edges.

Here's another simple 4-ingredient (if you use canned sweetened condensed milk) holiday recipe for you all: Christmas Fudge. I share this recipe every year because it's practically foolproof. No crumbling, no fussiness, no worries. 

Just perfect fudge, every time!

Ingredients:
3 cups semi-sweet chocolate morsels
1 can Eagle Brand Sweetened Condensed Milk (or homemade recipe)
Dash of salt
1.5 tsp vanilla

Optional toppings/decorations:
1/2 cup nuts (stir in, or crush and sprinkle on top)
Mini marshmallows
White Chocolate chips to melt and drizzle for decoration
Coconut flakes

Instructions:
1. Melt chocolate in a bowl over a water bath. Stir in sweetened condensed milk, salt, and vanilla. Combine until smooth.
2. Add any additional optional ingredients you want in the fudge (nuts, marshmallows). Pour & spread evenly into an 8×8 pan lined with wax or parchment paper. This is a great time to add optional toppers.
3. Refrigerate for 2 hours, or until set, and then remove from pan & paper and cover tightly with plastic wrap to avoid it drying out. If cutting into several pieces at once (sometimes mini cookie cutters are nice for this), set it out on the counter for 20 minutes or so to soften enough for neater, easier cuts.

These Rice Krispie treats look impressive because of the dipping chocolate and sprinkles, but they are a beginner-friendly favourite for sweet tooth, young and old! 

Simply make your favourite Rice Krispies square recipe on a cookie sheet (instead of a cake pan), cut the mixture into festive shapes (you don't have to pick Christmas trees!), dip them in chocolate, and measure your sprinkles with love!

Don't have a favourite Rice Krispie square recipe? Check out mine below, and let your creativity flow this holiday season!

Ingredients:
6 cups Rice Krispie cereal
40 large marshmallows
1/2 cup butter
1 tsp vanilla
1 1/2 cups white chocolate melting wafers
sprinkles

Instructions:
1. Melt butter, marshmallows, and butter in a large bowl in the microwave for approximately 5 minutes, setting the microwave one minute at a time and stirring in between.
2. Add Rice Krispies and press into a large cookie sheet. Allow to cool, then cut Christmas tree shapes with a cookie cutter.
3. Melt chocolate wafers and dip Rice Krispie treats. Add sprinkles if desired.

Butter tarts are a favourite sweet treat for many Canadians, and everyone seems to have their favourite way of making them. How do you like your butter tarts? Plain? With nuts, coconut, or raisins? I like my butter tarts plain, but especially around the holidays, I love to make my butter tarts with dried cranberries! 

Check out the full recipe below for this twist on a Canadian classic!

Ingredients:
1/2 cup butter
1 beaten egg
1 cup brown sugar
1 tbsp flour
1 tsp vanilla
2 tbsp cream
1 cup dried cranberries
16 tart pastry shells

Instructions:
1. Combine all ingredients (except shells) into a medium-high pot.
2. Stir until combined and melted, and remove from heat when boiled.
3. Fill tart shells.
4. Bake at 350 for 15 minutes.
5. Cool and serve.

These are one of my favourite, easy, I-keep-coming-back-for-more-even-though-I-probably-shouldn't Christmas treats: Almond Roca. Don't even bother trying to restrain yourself with these squares. There's a very good reason you'll often find them under the name "Christmas Crack" on Pinterest--they're just that good!

Find the full recipe below and make yourself a batch of these highly addictive sweets today! It's hard to share, but your loved ones will be oh-so-happy if you do!

Ingredients:
1 sleeve soda crackers (2 for a large cookie sheet)
1 cup butter
1 cup brown sugar
3/4 cup slivered almonds
1/2 cup milk chocolate chips, melted
1/2 cup white chocolate chips, melted

Instructions:
1. Line cookie sheet with tinfoil. Spray with cooking oil.
2. Layer crackers.
3. Bring butter and brown sugar to a boil for 2 minutes, stirring often.
4. Pour mixture over crackers and bake in a 325 oven for 10 minutes. Turn off oven. Sprinkle with almonds and return to the oven for 5 minutes.
5. Cool. Drizzle melted milk & white chocolate chips, alternating colours.
6. Cut in squares and serve.

I don't know about you, but my family goes through a lot of citrus fruit, especially in wintertime when I'm drying slices for wreaths, garlands, and other festive decor. Wondering what to do with all those leftover lemon, orange, and grapefruit peels? Save them and make this fun and easy natural all-purpose cleaner! 

Ingredients: 
citrus peels 
vinegar
cinnamon sticks (optional)

Instructions:
1. Fill a jar with citrus peels and cinnamon sticks and cover with vinegar—The cinnamon is optional, but I don’t recommend substituting it with ground cinnamon!
2. Seal and let the jar sit for two weeks 
3. Strain and keep the liquid—this is now your cleaning concentrate!
4. Add three parts water to one part cleaning solution to a spray bottle
5. Use as an all-purpose cleaner around your home!

I've seen lots about the concept of wintering lately on my Instagram feed, and I feel like I have been in a season of wintering for... maybe this entire year. Even though my personal wintering season may have lasted a whole year, I very much feel it right now on the winter solstice. So many times when I think, "I should do this new idea," I should update this post," or "I would love to do this new thing," I do a gut check, and my gut says, 

"No. You need more rest." 

While, on the one hand, it can be very upsetting to be in a season of wintering when others are in a season of summering, I know in my heart that whenever the wintering season is over, a season of new ideas will flourish. So, with that in mind, happy winter solstice!

Have you been feeling in a season of wintering lately? Let me know in the comments!
 
P.S. From the feed, it might seem that I am not wintering, but most of everything you see here is repurposed content or because of my wonderful writer, Siarra, who is writing these words right now. (Don't worry, I told her to say that!)

I had so looked forward to taking a pottery class. In fact, I'd been probably dreaming about it for at least 3 or 4 years. And this was the year it finally happened! While I tried to curb my expectations about how good I would be or how fun it would be, I just couldn't do it. 

I was honestly very disappointed.

Pottery doesn't come naturally to me. I am too tense, too tight, and my hands are, indeed, not slow. And more than one of my creations had to be destroyed because they just weren't worth continuing.

However, seven survivors made it! 

I'll admit, seeing my first and last pieces and how I improved from the beginning of class to the end is a very good feeling. And while I get a certain satisfaction from drinking coffee from my very crooked teacup, I am still left with this weird feeling. 

Were these seven pieces worth leaving my kids every Tuesday night for those weeks?

It requires so much effort to go away and do something for myself as a mother of four, with three of them still so little. From making sure my husband is home, knowing that bedtime will be horrible if I'm gone, and having all these conflicting emotions about spending time away, it isn't easy (to say the least). I hoped beyond hope that this class would feel worth it for the joy I got out of it (versus the guilt I felt about leaving the house and doing something for myself). 

Sadly, I have to say that it just didn't feel worth it. 

I want to be clear that this was no fault of the instructors. This is all to do with me, my situation, and what I had the capacity for at this stage of motherhood. I think it's just the pressure that if I'm doing something 100% for myself, it has to be perfect and amazing, or it doesn't feel worth it. Maybe I'll enjoy these pieces when I have something beautiful growing in them, but for now, they just kind of sit on my shelf as little reminders of guilt. 

I wish this post wasn't such a bummer, but I wanted to share an honest reflection, and I feel like many moms out there can relate. So, if something didn't go exactly how you wanted it to this year, it's ok. I'm right there with you!

#reflection #pottery #motherhoodunplugged

🌿Quick Gardening Tip🌿

Zone 3 gardeners, it's time to seed start the following plants...

1. Lisianthus 
Get your lisianthus started as soon as possible! The end of December or the beginning of January is best in Zone 3. In warmer climates (like Zone 5), it is acceptable to start your seeds into February if you have a longer growing season. You won't see your blooms if you do that in a cold climate, though! 

Learn more about growing lisianthus from seed in Zone 3 here: www.shiftingroots.com/grow-lisianthus-from-seed.

2. Eucalyptus 
It's also time to get your eucalyptus planted! Sooner than later is best. Start your seeds in January for the best chance at success in Zone 3. I've heard warmer season growers do it in February, but I'm pretty sure it is done in a greenhouse. 

Learn more about growing eucalyptus in a cold climate here: www.shiftingroots.com/how-to-grow-eucalyptus-for-cut-flowers-even-in-a-short-growing-season.

Are you a cold-climate gardener looking for a challenge? Try growing the luffa sponge!

In warmer climates, the luffa is reasonably easy to grow. In cold climates with short growing seasons? Not so much.⁠ If you start your seeds too late, you risk getting no gourds.⁠ If you expose it to frost? Dead⁠. And it will stop growing for a month if you expose it to temperatures lower than 10°C/50°F! 

Trust me, I've learned from experience.

If you're ready for the challenging (yet rewarding) experience of growing these finicky plants, check out the full blog post here: www.shiftingroots.com/how-to-grow-luffa-sponge-in-cold-climates-even-zone-3.
